case_name: Syed M. Karim v. Mst. Bibi Sakina

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 647 of 1962

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 647 of 1962.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated December 3, 1959 of the Patna High Court in Appeal from Appellate Decree No. 642 of 1957

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree ,dated December 3, 1959 of the Patna High Court in Appeal from Appellate Decree No. 642 of 1957.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on February 14, 1964 by HIDAYATULLAH, J.

anchor.surface_text: February 14, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J.-This is an appeal by special leave against the judgment of the High Court of Patna reversing the concurrent judgments of the two courts below, and ordering the dismissal of the suit of the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant is Syed M. Karim, son of Syed Aulad Ali

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is Syed M. Karim, son of one Syed Aulad Ali and the respondent Mst. Bibi Sakina  defendant No.11  is transferee of the properties in dispute from Hakir Alam  defendant No. 2 , son-in-law of Syed Aulad Ali.

facts.text: Respondent Mst. Bibi Sakina is defendant No.11 and transferee of the properties from Hakir Alam defendant No.2, son-in-law of Syed Aulad Ali

anchor.surface_text: and the respondent Mst. Bibi Sakina  defendant No.11  is transferee of the properties in dispute from Hakir Alam  defendant No. 2 , son-in-law of Syed Aulad Ali. The appellant, in his turn, is a transferee of the same properties from his father Syed Aulad Ali.

facts.text: Appellant is transferee of the properties from his father Syed Aulad Ali

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, in his turn, is a transferee of the same properties from his father Syed Aulad Ali. The suit was brought for declaration of Title and confirmation of possession or in the alternative for delivery thereof against several defendants in respect of this and other properties.

facts.text: Suit brought for declaration of title and confirmation of possession or in alternative delivery thereof against several defendants

anchor.surface_text: The suit was brought for declaration of Title and company- firmation of possession or in the alternative for delivery thereof against several defendants in respect of this and other properties. We are number companycerned in this appeal with the other defendants or the other properties.

facts.text: Syed Aulad Ali purchased the suit properties on May 28, 1914 at a court sale benami in the name of his son-in-law Hakir Alam

anchor.surface_text: This part of the appellants suit was based on the allegation that Syed Aulad Ali had purchased the suit properties on May 28, 1914 at a companyrt sale, benami in the name of his son-in-law Hakir Alam. The reason for the benami purchase was that under the rules of the Darbhanga Raj where Syed Aulad Ali was employed,

facts.text: Benami purchase because under rules of Darbhanga Raj where Syed Aulad Ali employed, persons in certain capacities prohibited from purchasing at court sales

anchor.surface_text: The reason for the benami purchase was that under the rules of the Darbhanga Raj where Syed Aulad Ali was employed, persons serving in certain capacities were prohibited from purchasing at companyrt sales. The sale certi- ficate was issued in the name of Hakir Alam who was then living with Syed Aulad Ali.

facts.text: Sale certificate issued in the name of Hakir Alam who was living with Syed Aulad Ali

anchor.surface_text: The sale certi- ficate was issued in the name of Hakir Alam who was then living with Syed Aulad Ali. On January 6, 1950, Syed Aulad Ali sold the property to his son the present appellant and Hakir Alam sold the property in his turn to Bibi Sakina and the present suit was filed for the above reliefs.

facts.text: On January 6, 1950, Syed Aulad Ali sold the property to his son the present appellant

anchor.surface_text: On January 6, 1950, Syed Aulad Ali sold the property to his son the present appellant and Hakir Alam sold the property in his turn to Bibi Sakina and the present suit was filed for the above reliefs. In this appeal, it has been stressed by the appellant that the findings clearly establish the benami nature of the transaction of 1914.

facts.text: Hakir Alam sold the property to Bibi Sakina

anchor.surface_text: and Hakir Alam sold the property in his turn to Bibi Sakina and the present suit was filed for the above reliefs.

facts.text: Patna High Court reversed concurrent judgments of two courts below and ordered dismissal of the suit

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave against the judgment of the High Court of Patna reversing the companycurrent judgments of the two companyrts below, and ordering the dismissal of the suit of the appellant. The appellant is Syed M. Karim, son of one Syed Aulad Ali and the respondent Mst. Bibi Sakina  defendant No.11  is transferee of the properties in dispute from Hakir Alam  defendant No. 2 , son-in-law of Syed Aulad Ali.

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal, it has been stressed by the appellant that the findings clearly establish the benami nature of the transaction of 1914. This is, perhaps, true but the appellant cannot avail himself of it.

facts.text: High Court did not accept plea of adverse possession by Syed Aulad Ali and plaintiff

anchor.surface_text: The High Court did number accept this case. Such a case is, of companyrse, open to a plaintiff to make if his possession is disturbed. If the possession of the real owner ripens into title under the Limitation Act and he is dispossessed, he can sue to obtain possession,for he does number then rely on the benami nature of the transaction.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the plea of adverse possession was number raised in the suit and reversed the decision of the two companyrts below.

s. 66 of the Code of Civil Procedure bars it. That section provides that no suit shall be maintained against any person claiming title under a purchase certified by the Court on the ground that the purchase was made on behalf of the plaintiff or on behalf of someone through whom the plaintiff claims.

concepts.interpretation: Bars any suit against a person claiming title under a court-certified purchase on the ground that it was benami for the plaintiff or his predecessor; protects certified purchaser and claimants through them; second subsection permits suits by third-party creditors against the real owner, but not by transferees from the real owner, to avoid defeating the first subsection.

issues.text: Whether the appellant's claim based on the benami nature of the 1914 court sale transaction is barred by section 66 of the Code of Civil Procedure, including whether a transferee from the real owner qualifies under the second subsection as a third person creditor

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal, it has been stressed by the appellant that the findings clearly establish the benami nature of the transaction of 1914. This is, perhaps, true but the appellant cannot avail himself of it. The appellants claim based upon the benami nature of the transaction cannot stand because s. 66 of the Code of Civil Procedure bars it. That section provides that no suit shall be maintained against any person claiming title under a purchase certified by the Court on the ground that the purchase was made on behalf of the plaintiff or on behalf of someone through whom the plaintiff claims.

issues.text: Whether the alternative claim that the title of the certified purchaser was extinguished by adverse possession of the real owner and plaintiff was properly pleaded and proved, without reliance on the benami nature

anchor.surface_text: As an alternative, it was contended before us that the title of Hakir Alam was extinguished by long and uninterrupted adverse possession of Syed Aulad Ali and after him of the plaintiff. The High Court did not accept this case. Such a case is, of course, open to a plaintiff to make if his possession is disturbed. If the possession of the real owner ripens into title under the Limitation Act and he is dispossessed, he can sue to obtain possession,for he does not then rely on the benami nature of the transaction.

arguments.court_reasoning: This is, perhaps, true but the appellant cannot avail himself of it

arguments.claim: Appellant's claim based on benami nature cannot stand because s. 66 CPC bars suit against person claiming title under certified purchase on ground purchase made on behalf of plaintiff or predecessor

anchor.surface_text: The appellants claim based upon the benami nature of the transaction cannot stand because s. 66 of the Code of Civil Procedure bars it. That section provides that no suit shall be maintained against any person claiming title under a purchase certified by the Court on the ground that the purchase was made on behalf of the plaintiff or on behalf of someone through whom the plaintiff claims. Formerly, the opening words were, no suit shall be maintained against a certified purchaser. and the change was made to protect not only the certified purchaser but any person claiming title under a purchase certified by the Court. The protection is thus available not only against the real purchaser but also against anyone claiming through him. In the present case, the appellant as plaintiff was hit by the section and the defendants were protected by it,

arguments.claim: Case falls within second subsection of s. 66 CPC allowing suit by third person against property to satisfy claim against real owner; transfer to appellant qualifies as such claim by transferee

anchor.surface_text: It is contended that the case falls within the second sub- section under which a suit is possible at the instance of a third person who wishes to proceed against the property. though ostensibly sold to the certified purchaser, on the ground that it is liable to satisfy a claim of such third person against the real owner. Reliance is placed upon the transfer by Syed Aulad Ali in favour of the appellant which is described as a claim by the transferee against the real owner.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: er which a suit is possible at the instance of a third person who wishes to proceed against the property. though ostensibly sold to the certified purc

arguments.court_reasoning: Words refer to claim of creditors and not claims of transferees; latter dealt with in first subsection; accepting would defeat policy of law and make first subsection dead letter

arguments.claim: Second subsection of s. 66 CPC refers only to creditors' claims against real owner, not transferees from real owner

anchor.surface_text: The words of the second sub-section refer to the claim of creditors and not to the claims of transferees. The latter are dealt with in first sub-section, and if the meaning sought to be placed on the second sub-section by the appellant were to be accepted, the entire policy of the law would be defeated by the real purchaser making a transfer to another and the first sub-section would become almost a dead letter. In our opinion, such a construction cannot be accepted and the plaintiffs suit must be held to be barred under s. 66 of the Code.

arguments.court_reasoning: Agree with High Court; reading plaint as whole, case based on possession after purchase not stated; cites Bishun Dayal v. Kesho Prasad where Judicial Committee rejected without proper plea

arguments.claim: Plea of adverse possession is raised; no specific plea necessary per precedents Sukan v. Krishanand and Sri Bhagwan Singh v. Ram Basi, or alternatively prayer clause constitutes proper plea

anchor.surface_text: The plea of adverse possession is raised here. Reliance is placed before us on Sukan v. Krishanand 1  and Sri Bhagwan Singh and others v. Ram Basi and others 1  to submit that such a plea is not necessary and alternatively, that if a plea is required, what can be considered a proper plea. But these two cases can hardly help the appellant.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: on the benami nature of the transaction. But the alternative claim must be clearly made andproved. The High Court held that the plea of adverse posses

arguments.court_reasoning: Cases can hardly help; each case determined by its plaint allegations; no doubt plaint mentions continued possession but not that it was adverse

arguments.claim: Adverse possession requires adequacy in continuity, publicity, extent, specific plea showing when it became adverse; long possession or prayer clause insufficient; no evidence possession became adverse

anchor.surface_text: There is no suggestion that Syed Aulad Ali ever asserted any hostile title against him or that a dispute with regard to ownership and possession had ever arisen. Adverse possession must be adequate in continuity, in publicity and extent and a plea is required at the least to show when possession becomes adverse so that the starting point of limitation against the party affected can be found. There is no evidence here when possession became adverse, if it at all did, and a mere suggestion in the relief clause that there was an uninterrupted possession for several 12 years or that the plaintiff had acquired an absolute title was not enough to raise such a plea. Long possession is not necessarily adverse possession and the prayer clause is not a substitute for a plea. The cited cases need hardly be considered, because each case must be determined upon the allegations in the plaint in that case. It is sufficient to point out that in Bishun Dayal v. Kesho Prasad and another A.I.R. 1940 Cal. 202, the Judicial Committee did not accept an alternative case based on possession after purchase without a proper plea. Reading the plaint as a whole, we agree with the High Court that a case based on possession after the purchase was not stated in the plaint and the decision of the High Court in the circumstances of this case was therefore proper.

holdings.text: The appellants claim based upon the benami nature of the transaction cannot stand because s. 66 of the Code of Civil Procedure bars it.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants claim based upon the benami nature of the transaction cannot stand because s. 66 of the Code of Civil Procedure bars it. That section provides that no suit shall be maintained against any person claiming title under a purchase certified by the Court on the ground that the purchase was made on behalf of the plaintiff or on behalf of someone through whom the plaintiff claims.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 66 bars suits against certified purchasers or persons claiming under them on benami grounds; amended to extend protection beyond just certified purchaser; applies directly to appellant as transferee from real owner against respondent transferee from certified purchaser.

holdings.text: The words of the second sub-section refer to the claim of creditors and not to the claims of transferees. The latter are dealt with in first sub-section... In our opinion, such a construction cannot be accepted and the plaintiffs suit must be held to be barred under s. 66 of the Code.

anchor.surface_text: The words of the second sub-section refer to the claim of creditors and not to the claims of transferees. The latter are dealt with in first sub-section, and if the meaning sought to be placed on the second sub-section by the appellant were to be accepted, the entire policy of the law would be defeated by the real purchaser making a transfer to another and the first sub-section would become almost a dead letter.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Second subsection limited to third-party creditors enforcing claims against real owner via property; transferee from real owner covered by first subsection; alternative interpretation would defeat legislative policy protecting certified purchases.

holdings.text: Adverse possession must be adequate in continuity, in publicity and extent and a plea is required at the least to show when possession becomes adverse so that the starting point of limitation against the party affected can be found.

anchor.surface_text: There is no suggestion that Syed Aulad Ali ever asserted any hostile title against him or that a dispute with regard to ownership and possession had ever arisen. Adverse possession must be adequate in continuity, in publicity and extent and a plea is required at the least to show when possession becomes adverse so that the starting point of limitation against the party affected can be found.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Requirements for adverse possession include continuity, publicity, extent, and specific pleading of starting point; no evidence of hostility, dispute, or timing here.

holdings.text: Long possession is not necessarily adverse possession and the prayer clause is not a substitute for a plea... Reading the plaint as a whole, we agree with the High Court that a case based on possession after the purchase was not stated in the plaint and the decision of the High Court in the circumstances of this case was therefore proper.

anchor.surface_text: There is no evidence here when possession became adverse, if it at all did, and a mere suggestion in the relief clause that there was an uninterrupted possession for several 12 years or that the plaintiff had acquired an absolute title was not enough to raise such a plea. Long possession is not necessarily adverse possession and the prayer clause is not a substitute for a plea.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants claim based upon the benami nature of the transaction cannot stand because s. 66 of the Code of Civil Procedure bars it. That section provides that no suit shall be maintained against any person claiming title under a purchase certified by the Court on the ground that the purchase was made on behalf of the plaintiff or on behalf of someone through whom the plaintiff claims.

Reading the plaint as a whole, we agree with the High Court that a case based on possession after the purchase was number stated in the plaint and the decision of the High Court in the circumstances of this case was therefore proper.

anchor.surface_text: The words of the second sub-section refer to the claim of creditors and not to the claims of transferees. The latter are dealt with in first sub-section, and if the meaning sought to be placed on the second sub-section by the appellant were to be accepted, the entire policy of the law would be defeated by the real purchaser making a transfer to another and the first sub-section would become almost a dead letter.

Reading the plaint as a whole, we agree with the High Court that a case based on possession after the purchase was number stated in the plaint and the decision of the High Court in the circumstances of this case was therefore proper.

anchor.surface_text: There is no evidence here when possession became adverse, if it at all did, and a mere suggestion in the relief clause that there was an uninterrupted possession for several 12 years or that the plaintiff had acquired an absolute title was not enough to raise such a plea. Long possession is not necessarily adverse possession and the prayer clause is not a substitute for a plea.

Reading the plaint as a whole, we agree with the High Court that a case based on possession after the purchase was number stated in the plaint and the decision of the High Court in the circumstances of this case was therefore proper.
